comment: The definition of relation given here implies that a relation is a set of ordered pairs. But such a set is a subset of infinitely many Cartesian products AxB. To determine if a relation is reflexive, you need to know which AxB you're talking about. E.g. the set {(x,x)} is a relation from {x} to {x} but also a relation from {x,y} to {x,y}. It is thus reflexive on {x} but not reflexive on {x,y}, so reflexivity is not actually a property of {(x,x)} itself. A better definition is to say that a relation is a triple (A,B,P), where the pair-set P is a subset of AxB. With that definition, it is clear from the relation itself whether it is reflexive or not.

If something is symmetric, it certainly isn't antisymmetric, and if something is antisymmetric, then it certainly isn't symmetric. So why isn't is opposite?
Is it true that if something is not symmetric then it is certainly symmetric?

​ @stv3qbhxjnmmqbw835  The negation of antisymmetry is "when xRy and yRx, x =/= y". Meanwhile, the symmetry is described by the following statement: "if xRy, then yRx for all x,y". Are those statements equivalent? Analogously, the negation of symmetry is "there are some x,y for which xRy => yRx is not true". Is it the same as "xRy and yRx => x=y", i.e. the antisymmetry?
@daniileliseev9362  Hi! Correct me if I'm wrong, but I think that that's not the right negation you applied there.
